Christofer, I believe that adding hidden nodes over evolution can work
and =
that it will eventually turn out quite effective.  The problem is
to discov=
er the best way to it in the substrate.  There are a lot of
possibilities a=
nd I think the best way to begin to sort through them
is to give the best i=
deas a try and observe the effects.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "chr=
istofer_fransson"
<christofer_fransson@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> In the food ga=
thering experiment the phenotype network is fixed.
> The CPPN evolve to giv=
e better and better weights to the network.
> 
> Assuming that the CPPN out=
put can be visualized as an "image". 
> 
> Now: Let say that a hidden node =
in the phenotype network is added 
> during evolution. Can some prediction =
about how the "image" changes 
> be done?
> 
> If so, would it be possible =
to train a CPPN like network that take 
> the "image" as input and as outpu=
t try to place hidden nodes to the 
> phenotype where they would do the mos=
t use?
> 
> If it is possible to add a lot of hidden nodes to the phenotype=
, 
> forcing the CPPN to change the evolutionary course, can one add 
> hid=
den nodes to the phenotype network and still keep the CPPN in 
> course? 
>=
 
> /Christofer
>
